name: Southerner Raider
flavor_text: When a particularly harsh winter has passed, Men from the South may assemble war parties and look for some isolated homestead to plunder.

name: Southerner Champion
flavor_text: A Southerner Champion may be a chieftain from Dunland, a bandit lord capable of uniting a number of fractious warriors into a small army, or just a particularly vicious brigand.

name: Footpad
flavor_text: A cowardly bandit, ready to rob a defenceless victim, but capable of ambushing a lonely companion with the help of others.

name: Ruffian Chief
flavor_text: Tougher or simply fiercer, a chief is a ruffian who has reached the top with the help of a sharper mind, or blade.

name: Highway Robber
flavor_text: More dangerous than a common brigand, a highway robber is used to a life in the Wild, and has learned how to deal with armed victims.

name: Great Orc Chief
flavor_text: Great Orcs are often encountered as leaders and chieftains of their weaker-blooded relatives.

name: Great Orc Bodyguard
flavor_text: Less cunning than those who lead them, these fell creatures protect their captains at the cost of their lives.

name: Goblin Archer
flavor_text: A Goblin Archer is an Orc chosen for his keen eyes. His ability to see in the dark, coupled with a steady hand, lets him shoot arrows with precision by night or day.

name: Orc-Chieftain
flavor_text: Only the most wicked and cruel Orcs live long enough to become chieftains and lead their tribe or warband to battle.

name: Orc Guard
flavor_text: The strongest and boldest Orcs are equipped with the toughest armour they can find or put together, and are placed to keep watch on an area wielding a sword and sturdy shield.

name: Orc Soldier
flavor_text: Often armed with characteristic bent swords, Orc Soldiers are a loud, undisciplined lot. Only a forceful chieftain with a cruel whip and a sharp blade can keep them in line.

name: Great Cave-Troll
flavor_text: Feared by its own handlers, a Great Cave-troll is sent by Orcs to smash the defences and the morale of the foes they fear the most.

name: Cave-Troll Slinker
flavor_text: Used to live in the depths of the earth, a Cave-troll Slinker often hunts alone and in the dark, relying on its acute sense of smell.

name: Stone-Troll Robber
flavor_text: A Stone-troll Robber’s appearance, while always frightful, is made less monstrous by their tendency to wear simple clothes, cook their food and use tools like drinking jugs and barrels.

name: Stone-Troll Chief
flavor_text: Small groups of Stone-trolls may band together around a stronger member of their breed, to attack caravans of merchants or isolated farmhouses.

name: Barrow-Wight
flavor_text: Sent to the hills of Tyrn Gorthad by the Witch-king of Angmar to plague his enemies in the wars against Arnor, a Barrow-wight appears as a tall, dark figure, with cold eyes lit by a pale light.

name: Fell Wraith
flavor_text: Fell Wraiths appear as crooked wanderers, roaming among ancient ruins, wrapped in cloaks hiding their spectral features. Their flesh is almost transparent, and their eyes seem to glow like embers.

name: Marsh-Dwellers
flavor_text: The Marsh-dwellers are shambling humanoid creatures with a clammy pale flesh, like that of a corpse left to rot in the water. A fell light in their small eyes suggests a wicked vitality and intent.

name: Wild Wolf
flavor_text: The average Warg is slightly larger than an ordinary Wolf, and much more vicious. It can be encountered in a pack, but also as a solitary hunter or scout, ready to howl and alert other Wargs and evil creatures for miles around.

name: Wolf-Chieftain
flavor_text: Greater in stature, cruelty and cunning than ordinary Wargs, a Wolf-chieftain is called upon by its lesser kin to deal with serious threats, like bands of travelling adventurers trespassing into Warg territory.

name: Hound Of Sauron
flavor_text: Chosen for its ferocity and malicious intelligence, a Hound of Sauron is a minion of the Dark Lord, a servant sent on a precise errand, be it the gathering of forces for a coming war, the hunt for a specific individual, or spying on an area.
